The  Government  has  demonstrated  strong  commitment  to  poverty 
reduction  and  governance  reforms,  articulated  initially  through  its 
Decentralization  Plan  2000;  reaffirmed  in  the  2001  Interim  Poverty 
Reduction  Strategy  Paper;  and  progressively  implemented  through  a 
range  of  measures  to  address  issues  relating  to  chronic  access  to 
justice,  basic  service  delivery,  political  representation,  and  gender 
equity issues. Decentralization is a complex policy package to support 
the  role  of 
poverty  and  governance  reforms  by  reengineering 
government;  thoroughly  restructuring  Federal,  provincial,  and  local 
governmental  relations;  and  creating  a  third  tier  of  government 
comprising  democratically  elected  councils  at  the  district,  tehsil  (sub-
district), and union levels.

environment;  and  entrenched  traditions  of  privilege,  exclusivity,  and

implementation  of  decentralization  are  arguably  the  boldest  ever 
undertaken  by  a  developing  country.  The  legal  framework  for  these 
reforms,  including  ordinances  for  accounts,  audit,  police,  and  local 
government, is already in place. Political decentralization, the first step 
in  the  governance  reforms,  occurred  over  a  remarkably  short  time 
between  March  2000  and  August  2001,  when  elections  were  held  to

Debt,  Discretion,  and  Pro-Poor  Spending.  Chronic  fiscal  and  external  deficits  have 
resulted in the accumulation of large domestic and external debt. Total debt (both domestic and 
external)  equaled  115%  of  GDP  in  FY2001;  interest  payments  on  total  debt  accounted  for 
almost 50% of the total government current expenditure; and, even after debt rescheduling, the 
external  debt  service  ratio  was  over  23%.  Against  the  backdrop  of  heavy  indebtedness, 
Pakistan negotiated an International Monetary Fund (IMF) Standby Program amounting to $600 
million  in  November  2000.    After  successful  completion  of  the  Standby  Program,  the  IMF 
approved  a  three-year  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Facility  (PRGF)  on  7  December  2001 
and, during the same month signed the third debt restructuring agreement with the Paris Club. 
During 2002, following the successful rescheduling of its bilateral debt obligations and increased 
inflow  of  remittances  and  external  agency  funds,  gross  foreign  exchange  reserves  have 
increased  to  more  than  $5  billion,  the  highest  amount  ever,  and  the  rupee  has  stabilized  and 
strengthened.

Bold Governance Reform for Service Delivery and Political Representation. In light 
of  the  chronic  problems  facing  inclusive  public  service  delivery  and  political  representation, 
Pakistan’s recent governance reforms are among the boldest ever undertaken by a developing 
country. The legal framework for these reforms, including ordinances for accounts, audit, police, 
and  local  government,  is  already  in  place  and  is  expected  to  be  given  a  durable  legal  status. 
Political  decentralization,  the  first  step  in  the  governance  reforms,  has  occurred  over  a 
remarkably short time. Between March 2000 and August 2001, the Government abandoned the 
former  system  of  administrative  deconcentration,  and  elections  were  completed  to  install 
representative councils at three levels of local government. Commitments to gender reform and 
social  development  are  seen  by  the  Government  as  integral  to  decentralization:  a  key  break 
from  Pakistan’s  political  past  was  accomplished  with  30%  of  seats  reserved  for  women.  As  a 
result a large number of women were elected, and they now comprise 32% of councilors. Efforts 
to  provide  an  enabling  environment  for  improved  state  –  nongovernment  organization 
relationships (e.g., policy, legal, and institutional arrangements) have also reached an advanced 
stage.  Pakistan’s  present  decentralization  echoes  aspects  of  efforts  made  on  previous 
occasions  to  empower  local  authorities,  but  certain  features  distinguish  contemporary  policy 
(paras. 8 - 15; see also Appendix 3).

servants belonged either to the Federal or provincial cadres. For instance, high-level provincial 
education  officials  belonged  to  the  Federal  cadre,  as  did  the  appointed  chief  district  officer, 
whereas  district  education  officers,  teachers,  and  other  education  officials  belonged  to  the

39. 
The Program supports reform actions for which the Government has demonstrated clear 
and  sustained  commitment,  that  is,  the  creation  of  rule-based,  democratically  elected, 
appropriately resourced local governments operating according to clearly established norms of 
public  participation,  access  to  information,  and  accountability.  However,  the  Program  has  five 
additional  important  features  that  build  on  ADB’s  key  role  in  support  for  decentralization  and 
related  reforms  in  support  of  poverty  reduction.  First,  it  is  one  of  two  key  core  governance 
reform investments by ADB that could favorably impact on the effectiveness of the majority of 
proposed lending under the CSP (Supplementary Appendix D), while building on a major ADB 
TA  activity  to  design  new  systems  for  decentralized  financing,  planning,  management,  and 
delivery of local government services. These systems, and corresponding operational modules 
and  training  materials,  now  tested  and  approved,  are  ready  for  nationwide  implementation. 
Second,  the  DSP  also  supports  the  extension  nationwide  of  reformed  Federal,  provincial,  and 
local  level  systems  for  accounting  and  independent  audit  through  a  combined  effort  with  the 
World  Bank.  Third,  the  Program  uniquely  combines  support  for  all  three  relations  of 
accountability  recognized  internationally  as  crucial  to  effective  devolved  governance.26  Fourth, 
the  DSP  articulates  both  ADB's  and  the  Government’s  commitment  to  gender  reforms  (i)  by 
embedding  gender  considerations  into  all  systems  and  procedures,  and  institutional  and 
capacity  development  activities  supported  by  the  DSP;  and  (ii)  through  a  dedicated  TA  loan, 
entitled  Gender  and  Governance  Mainstreaming,  to  support  implementation  of  a  GRAP 
following its approval by the Federal and province cabinets. Fifth, early indications are that the 
DSP may become an attractive modality for TA from bilateral agencies (e.g., DFID and CIDA).

instability  derived  from  either  border  conflict  with  India  or  destabilization  of  the  regime  by

cause  redirection  of  fiscal  resources,  and  undermine  the  key  principle  of  predictability  and 
timeliness  in  fiscal  transfers.  Second,  the  uncertain  political  climate  is  generating  longer  term 
economic  costs  in  lost  revenues  from  trade,  tourism,  international  communications,  and 
investment.  The  risks  are  that  social  unrest  owing  to  loss  of  safety  nets,  jobs,  and  health 
services  could  turn  the  population  against  the  Government,  and  against  its  newest  local 
representatives  that  have  the  fewest  means  at  their  disposal  to  correct  macroeconomic 
problems. Third, the patterns of exclusion and disempowerment facing women in Pakistan are 
deeply bound into cultural and political traditions, reinforced by profound inequalities in literacy 
and  assets.  While  the  Government’s  commitment  to  women’s  political  representation  is 
unprecedented, rapid change in on-ground realities cannot be expected, which may weaken the 
commitment to the reforms of the largest disadvantaged population in Pakistan.   
 
80. 
There  are  three  micro  risks.  First,  Pakistan  has  only  marginal  experience  with  local 
politics, consensus building, and public accountability of leaders. The highest political authority, 
that is, nazims, at all three tiers of local government belong to the local elite. Unless councilors 
are able to organize there is a risk that government institutions will continue to be manipulated 
to protect elite interests. Further, local conflicts could release violent passions and unintended 
consequences for local development. Political education efforts may not occur quickly enough to 
prevent  wider  chaos  from  taking  hold  of  local  governance.  Second,  most  local  officials  lack 
capacity to perform the many new roles assigned them, from managing educational services to 
preparing development budgets. Capacity building may not lead to skills, or worse still, may end 
up as more unused skills of little use in fulfilling duties in unchallenging official roles. The skills 
may not translate into better decisions. Third, underlying administrative systems are lacking to 
perform such basic functions as procuring equipment, accounting for the order and its delivery, 
committing budget resources for the order over the course of a FY, and evaluating the value for

Poverty Analysis: Poverty and Governance 

2. 
Poverty in Pakistan exhibits six features of direct relevance to a governance support and 
poverty  reduction  program  such  as  Decentralization  Support  Program  (DSP).  First,  income 
distribution is relatively equal compared with countries of similar income level, which suggests 
both  that  generalized  benefits  may  be  obtained  from  pro-poor  interventions  and  that 
nonspecifically targeted interventions will tend to benefit rather than exclude the poor. Second, 
although  the  incidence  of  poverty  is  high,  transitory  poverty  rates  are  also  high.  This  implies 
that,  rather  than  focusing  on  the  symptoms  of  poverty,  such  as  income  gap  or  social  sector 
indicators, it is important to focus on the probable causes of entry and exit into poverty, that is, 
vulnerability to poverty. The poverty rationale for the DSP is in large measure supported by the 
evident role of the state, especially the local state, in exacerbating the conditions of vulnerability. 
Third,  a  large  proportion  of  the  poor  are  dependent  on  informal  sector  wage  labor  and  are 
therefore particularly vulnerable to rent seeking by local public officials responsible for regulating 
their  livelihood  activities.  The  fourth  and  fifth  features  of  poverty  provide  further  focus  on  the 
vulnerability/governance  nexus.  While  relatively  egalitarian  in  terms  of  “income  poverty,”  the 
capacity of the poor to access public entitlements–like political processes or goods and services 
that  determine  human  development–contrasts  strikingly  with  that  of  the  rich.  For  instance, 
literacy,  which  is  critically  important  in  awareness  of  and  access  to  entitlements,  is  highly 
unequal.  There  are  tremendous  disparities  in  human  development  (defined  as  enlarging 
people's choices in a way that enables them to lead longer, healthier, and fuller lives). Finally, 
and  not  least  important,  a  sixth  feature  stands  out  in  the  poor's  perceptions  of  poverty:  they 
highlight  increasing  insecurity  and  vulnerability  arising  from  sectarian  violence,  declining  law 
and order, and the unresponsiveness of state officials to their needs and interests.

The  vulnerable  poor  in  Pakistan  are  especially  affected  by  their  relations  with  a 
dysfunctional  and  predatory  local  state.  Vulnerability  is  exacerbated  by  the  everyday

regulating economic activities, who typically extract rent from informal sector workers; (ii) by the 
corruption of local cadre/officials, which hampers access to public goods and services – health, 
education,  land  management, etc.;  and (iii) by the failure of government institutions to provide 
law and order and security, the primary enabling condition of pro-poor development.

A. 

Context 

Poverty and Gender. Despite some improvement over the last 30 years, the status of 
1. 
women in Pakistan is appalling. In the absence of gender-disaggregated, poverty-related data, a 
systematic gender analysis of poverty process remains elusive, but it is increasingly evident that 
poverty is feminized: women bear a disproportionately high share of the burden of poverty within 
the family and society. Moreover, the poorer the family, the higher is the likelihood of significant 
dependence  on  female  labor.    Global  comparators  give  some  indication  of  gender  poverty  in 
Pakistan. In the United Nations Development Programme's Gender-related Development Index 
2000, Pakistan ranks 135 of 174 countries. On the Gender Empowerment Measurement 1999, 
Pakistan ranks 100th out of 102 countries measured. The social indicators for women’s status 
are  the  poorest  in  the  region.  Female  literacy  is  only  29%  as  compared  with  a  literacy  rate  of 
55%  for  men.  Pakistan  is  one  of  the  few  countries  where  the  male:female  ratio  is  reversed. 
There are 108 men to every 100 women. The female infant mortality rate is higher (85 per 1,000 
live  births)  than  that  of  male  children  (82  per  1,000).  Only  47%  of  female  children  are  fully 
immunized  as  compared  with  52%  of  boys.  Forty  percent  of  adult  women  suffer  from  anemia. 
Due to early marriages, repeated pregnancy without proper spacing, poor nutritional status, and 
lack of professional medical care during pregnancy and delivery of the child, maternal mortality 
rate remains high: 1 woman in every 38 dies from pregnancy-related causes. The female labor 
force participation rate is reported as only 13.6% as compared with 69.1% for males due to the 
concentration of women in the informal sector, which is undocumented and characterized by a 
higher level of exploitation.  According to the 1990-1991 Pakistan Integrated Household Survey, 
more than three fourths of the economically active women in urban areas are employed in the 
informal  sector.  The  legal  status  of  women  has  been  reduced  through  various  discriminatory 
laws.  Violence  against  women  remains  an  everyday  experience  across  the  class,  region,  and 
rural-urban divides.1

political parties women are not appointed to decision-making positions. Women’s representation 
in the central executive committee of two major political parties, the Pakistan Peoples Party and

Past Efforts at Decentralization. Since Independence Pakistan has seen at least four

Issues in Future Design and Implementation 

1. 

Contextual Issues 

20. 
Political/Economic  Instability.  As  indicated,  to  some  extent  the  decentralization 
program was a response to the risks of widespread political instability related to poor provincial 
delivery  of  local  service  or  services  reasonably  expected  by  local  residents.  This  prompted 
action  by  the  President  and  NRB.  Decentralization  now  must  be  implemented  in  the  same 
unstable  context,  through  a  new  tier  of  government  with  newly  designed  systems  and  mostly 
borrowed staff, which will be an important institutional challenge. NRB and successor agencies 
must  balance  the  need  to  reduce  centralization  of  control  (which  remains  from  the  provincial 
level  and  is  dependent  on  fiscal  transfers  from  the  center)  with  greater  regulation  of  local 
officials (to ensure accountability and responsiveness to voters and residents beyond their own 
personal  and  group  needs).  Put  another  way,  the  Government  needs  to  shift  the  current 
emphasis  from  command  and  control  by  provinces  of  local  units  to  regulation  of  delegated 
functions  through  systems  of  incentives  for  achievement  of  service  targets.  Successful 
institutional reorientation will require political and economic stability.  
 
21. 
The  majority  of  elected  councilors  are  new  in  politics.  However,  the  composition  of  the 
councils  reflects  social  and  class  hierarchy  that  already  exists  in  the  society.  There  is  a  clear 
class divide between the mayors and deputy mayors, and general councilors. Nazims (mayors) 
of  UCs  as  well  as  district  councils  belong  to  dominant  classes  and  influential  families,  while 
nearly  50%  of  the  council  members  come  from  the  marginalized  social  categories  –  women, 
peasants,  and  workers.  Since  the  majority  of  councilors  who  have  been  elected  to  reserved 
seats  have  entered  into  formal  local  politics  for  the  first  time,  they  lack  political  training  and 
skills. The vast majority of councilors in special seats belong to neither political parties nor civil 
society  organizations.  They  are  not  organized  and  do  not  have  a  collective  voice  to  affect  the 
decision-making  processes  of  their  councils.  In  the  initial  phase  of  the  functioning  of  local 
governments, it is evident that nazims have the tendency to act as patriarchs and undermine the 
participatory  process  that  is  fundamental  to  the  spirit  of  decentralization  by  taking  unilateral

sessions,  particularly  at  the  UC  level,  are  not  convened  regularly  as  stated  in  the  Local 
Government Ordinance (LGO), and issues are not debated exhaustively enough. Exclusionary 
and  nonparticipatory  planning  and  budgetary  processes  have  already  generated  a  sense  of 
powerlessness and frustration among councilors, especially among those who are representing 
disadvantaged  sections  of  the  society,  which  is  articulated  through  frequent  walkouts  from 
council meetings. The continuing social divisions within the councils may lead to destabilization 
of the political dimension of local government. 
 
22. 
The  nature  of  bureaucracy  in  Pakistan  is  another  barrier  in  forging  a  new  relationship 
between the executive and political branches of the administration. The bureaucracy had been 
enjoying  complete  control  and  power  over  the  instrumentalities  of  state  institutions  since  the 
independence of the country. Bureaucracy inherited centralized control, arrogance, and tradition 
from  the  preindependence  era,  when  the  colonial  power  delegated  a  great  deal  of  power  to 
district administrators. The Decentralization Plan shifts and reshapes the authority and power of 
the  bureaucracy  by  way  of  making  it  accountable  to  elected  public  representatives.  The 
bureaucracy  is  known  for  its  opposition  and  resistance  to  this  new  devolved  system  of  local 
governance.  The  continuing  tension  between  officials  and  local  representatives,  and  the 
nonresponsiveness and resistance of the former to the demands of changing relationships is a 
further deterrent to the development of effective local government institutions. 
 
23. 
Citizens  have  the  central  role  to  play  in  the  success  of  the  local  government  system. 
They are the primary stakeholders whose vested interests to improve their living conditions and 
access to public goods and services is dependent on the success of the new system. Their level 
of  political  consciousness  will  be  a  key  factor  in  determining  people’s  participation  in  local 
governance structures. Low investment in community-based organizations and local committees 
to empower them to hold the local institution accountable will not yield desired results 
 
24.  Most of the proposed support for decentralization reforms requires sequenced activities, 
which,  if  interrupted  by  political  crises,  could  result  in  loss  of  program  momentum.  Ideally, 
political  stability  and  continuing  support  will  remain  during  the  implementation  of  modern 
decentralization reforms. A fear of NRB from the very outset of the decentralization was reversal 
of reforms (recentralization) by later political (i.e., not self-appointed) governments. The latter is 
unlikely to occur now. The former can be remedied through design innovations in the program, 
e.g., entry and exit triggers, and flexibility to modify delivery of activities and achieve targets.  
 
In  addition,  weak  macroeconomic  performance  owing  in  part  to  the  effects  of  11

combining to reduce available revenues to finance the decentralization program, either through

program. Additional political instability, e.g., through threats of war with India, can only reduce

socioeconomic  state,  level  of  local  institutional  development,  as  well  as  the  decision-making

situation,  including  debt  service  burdens.  Provincial  variation  will  affect  the  implementation 
progress of the decentralization. The diversity will affect the pace and scope of reform.

1. 
Estimates  have  been  made  of  the  adjustment  costs  associated  with  the  reforms 
encompassed by the Decentralization Support Program (DSP) on the basis of two approaches. 
The first, the conventional approach, defines adjustment costs in terms of actual resource costs 
from  the  budget  viewpoint  of  local  governments  and  provinces  (here  termed  the  "economic" 
costs).  The  second  approach  acknowledges  that  decentralization  is  a  federally  initiated  policy 
and program, and that the key fiscal reforms will adversely impact on the Federal budget (here 
termed  the  "fiscal"  cost).  The  latter  remains  an  important  consideration:  First,  budgetary 
constraints  can  hamper  the  implementation  of  the  decentralization  reform.  Second,  the  reform 
has  primarily  been  a  creation  of  institutional  arrangements  and  capacities  at  the  local  level  in 
addition  to  decentralization  of  functions  and  staff  to  the  local  governments  and,  further,  at  the 
present, provincial functions have remained in place.  Given that most of these costs are to be 
met  from  fiscal  transfers  from  the  Federal  Government,  these  increased  resources  are  being 
moved with the rationale of meeting the costs of implementation of decentralization.
